tess3r
  • Home
  • Overview
  • Documentation

Estimates spatial population structure

tess3 estimates spatial population structure using a graph based non negative matrix factorization for several value of ancestry population number. After estimating the population structure is used to compute a Fst statistic for each locus. See references for more details.

tess3(X, XProba = NULL, coord, K, ploidy, lambda = 1, rep = 1, W = NULL,
  method = "projected.ls", max.iteration = 200, tolerance = 1e-05,
  openMP.core.num = 1, Q.init = NULL, mask = 0, algo.copy = TRUE,
  keep = "best", verbose = FALSE)

Arguments

X
A numeric matrix which corresponds to the genotype matrix. This matrix must be of size \(n \times L\) where \(n\) is the number of individual and \(L\) is the number of loci. Values of this matrix are integer corresponding to the number of variant alleles observed at a locus. If NULL, XProba is used.
XProba
A numeric matrix which correspond to the probability for the genotype. This matrix must be of size \(n \times (ploidy + 1)L\) where \(n\) is the number of individual, \(L\) is the number of loci. Values of this matrix are numeric between 0 and 1 corresponding to the genome probability. It is the matrix used in graph based non negative factorization matrix. If NULL, it is computed from the genotype matrix X. See reference for more details.
coord
The numeric matrix of size \(n \times 2\) where \(n\) is the number of individuals.
K
An integer vector which corresponds to the number of ancestral populations.
ploidy
An integer which corresponds to the number of set of chromosomes.
lambda
A numeric which corresponds to the spatial regularization parameter.
rep
The number of time the algorithm will be repeated for each value of K.
W
A numeric matrix which corresponds to the graph weiht matrix. If NULL, W it is computed as W[i,j] = exp( - (coord[i] - coord[j])^2 / sigma^2). Where coord[i] is the geographic coordinate for the individual i and sigma equals 5 percent of the average geographic distance between individuals.
method
"projected.ls" or "qp". If "projected.ls", an aleternated projected least squares algorithm is used. If "qp", an alternated quadratic programing algorithm is used. See references for more details
max.iteration
The max number of iteration of the optimization algorithm.
tolerance
A numeric which corresponds to the tolerance of the stopping criteria of the optimization algorithm.
openMP.core.num
If openMP is available on your computer, it is the number of core used by the algorithm.
Q.init
A numeric matrix which corresponds to the initial value of Q for the algorithm.
mask
If not NULL this the proportion of the data matrix which is masked to compute the cross validation criteria.
algo.copy
if TRUE data will be copy 1 time to speed the algorithm.
keep
If "best", for each value of K only result with best rmse will be keep. If "all", for each value of K all results will be keep and returned. This second option take more room in memory.
verbose
If TRUE more information are printed.

Value

An object of class tess3 which is a list of size length(K). Each element of this list is a list with:

K
The number of ancestral population.
tess3.run
If keep = "best", the tess3Main result with the best rmse. If keep = "all", a list of tess3Main result for each repetition.
rmse
The list of the root square mean error between XProba and tcrossprod(Q, G) for each repetition.
crossentropy
The list of the cross entropy error between XProba and tcrossprod(Q, G) for each repetition.
crossvalid.rmse
If masked not NULL. The list of the root square mean error between XProba[masked] and tcrossprod(Q, G)[masked] for each repetition.
crossvalid.crossentropy
If masked not NULL. The list of tcrossprod(Q, G)[masked] for each repetition.

Methods available for this class:

  • plot.tess3
  • summary.tess3
  • is.tess3
  • Gettess3res
  • qmatrix
  • pvalue

References

https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01222555/ http://biorxiv.org/content/early/2016/10/12/080291

See also

tess3Main, plot.tess3Q, barplot.tess3Q

Examples

library(tess3r)

# Arabidopsis thaliana data set
data(data.at)
genotype <- data.at$X
coordinates <- data.at$coord

# Run of tess3 algorithm
tess3.obj <- tess3(X = genotype, coord = coordinates, K = 1:4,
                   method = "projected.ls",
                   ploidy = 1)
#> Computing spectral decomposition of graph laplacian matrix: done
#> Main loop with 1 threads: 
#> : done
#> Computing spectral decomposition of graph laplacian matrix: done
#> Main loop with 1 threads: 
#> : done
#> Computing spectral decomposition of graph laplacian matrix: done
#> Main loop with 1 threads: 
#> : done
#> Computing spectral decomposition of graph laplacian matrix: done
#> Main loop with 1 threads: 
#> : done
#> 

# Plot error
plot(tess3.obj, pch = 19, col = "blue",
     xlab = "Number of ancestral populations",
     ylab = "Cross-validation score")

# Retrieve tess3 Q matrix for K = 3 clusters
q.matrix <- qmatrix(tess3.obj, K = 3)
## STRUCTURE-like barplot for the Q-matrix
barplot(q.matrix, border = NA, space = 0,
       xlab = "Individuals", ylab = "Ancestry proportions",
       main = "Ancestry matrix") -> bp
#> Use CreatePalette() to define color palettes.
#> 
axis(1, at = 1:nrow(q.matrix), labels = bp$order, las = 3, cex.axis = .4)
## Spatial interpolation of ancestry coefficient
my.colors <- c("tomato", "orange", "lightblue")
my.palette <- CreatePalette(my.colors, 9)
plot(q.matrix, coordinates, method = "map.max",
     main = "Ancestry coefficients",
     xlab = "Longitude", ylab = "Latitude",
     resolution = c(500,500), cex = .4,
     col.palette = my.palette)
This function required to attach maps namespace.

# Retrieve tess3 results for K = 3
p.values <- pvalue(tess3.obj, K = 3)
hist(p.values, col = "lightblue")
## Manhatan plot
plot(p.values, main = "Manhattan plot",
    xlab = "Locus id",
    ylab = "-log10(P-values)",
    cex = .3, col = "grey")
